head.title: U.S. Rules Out Force Over Iraq Inspections

hedline.hl1: U.S. Rules Out Force Over Iraq Inspections

block.p: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, speaking with reporters after addressing the United Nations General Assembly, said the United States would not use force to make Iraq allow the resumption of international arms inspections. The decision may help to maintain an international consensus on dealing with Iraq.

Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, speaking with reporters after addressing the United Nations General Assembly, said the United States would not use force to make Iraq allow the resumption of international arms inspections. The decision may help to maintain an international consensus on dealing with Iraq.

But she said that Iraq would risk attack if it undertook other provocations, like building up weapons of mass destruction or taking military action against the Kurds. And she added that the sanctions imposed in 1990 after Iraq invaded Kuwait would never be lifted unless Saddam Hussein permitted the new inspection commission, under Hans Blix, a Swedish arms control expert, to do its work.
